The most dangerous intersection in Barcelona

And other observations on car accidents in the city

Posted by on November 30, 2015

The most dangerous intersection in Barcelona

You guessed it: Avinguda Diagonal and Passeig de Gracia.

This technically counts as one intersection, right?

From 2010 to 2014, there were 129 accidents involving 165 victims and 248 vehicles. That's an average of one accident every two weeks.

Yikes.

But everywhere is kind of dangerous

The reality is that, relative to other comparable cities, Barcelona is a dangerous place. Sure, Rome is worse (who's surprised?), but Barcelona's got a lot of cars, a lot of motorcycles, a lot of old roads, and a lot of people trying to get from point A to point B. And all that commotion adds up - to an average of 9,235 accidents per year over the last 5 years, which sums up to more than 25 per day.

And it doesn't appear to be getting any better.

In 2010, there were just a hair over 9,000 accidents. In 2011, that number dropped to 8,809. Since then, however, the number of accidents has climbed by a few hundred per year, peaking at 9,660 in 2014 (the last year for which data are available). 25 a day.

When do accidents happen?

Who knows. As consistent as the yearly numbers are, there's a lot of variation by time and day. Afternoon is far worse than morning, for example. Stay off the roads in the afternoon. And weekdays (especially Friday) are far worse than weekends. Accumulation of fatigue from working?

Wouldn't be cool to see all the car accidents on one map?

Yes, that would be awesome:

So what's behind all these accidents?

Who knows. But apparently, football games prevent them!

We looked at every accident from 2010-2014, and every Barcelona football game during the same period. It turns out that, on average, game days are about

Status Days Accidents Daily Rate
No game 1572 40376 25.68
Game day 254 5802 22.84

One could surmise that football matches keep people inside (glued to their television screens) rather than on the road. In other words, football itself isn't causing anything, and is simply acting as a proxy for traffic density.

Is this the case? We don't think so. When we dig deeper, we find that the outcomeof the match matters more than the . Barcelonians crash more often when Bar√ßa loses.

That's crazy, right?

What's the mechanism for this? Two possible theories. (1) People just get mad and drive worse when their team loses, or (2) people live venues in a more staggered fashion after a victory than after a defeat (since post-victory parties are more likely than post-defeat parties).

Data sources, code, etc.

OpenDataBCN hosts the dataset for traffic accidents managed by the Guardia Urbana. It's a super interesting dataset with a lot more than what was explored here (mortality, number of injuries, etc.).

The code and data for this post (including source files, cleaning script, visualizations, etc.) can all be found on github.
